coredata.dc:title: (Oxalato)borate: The key ingredient for polyethylene oxide based composite electrolyte to achieve ultra-stable performance of high voltage solid-state LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2/lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Cheng, Samson Ho-Sum
Liu, Chen
Zhu, Fangyan
Zhao, Liang
Fan, Rong
Chung, Chi-Yuen
Tang, Jiaoning
Zeng, Xierong
He, Yan-Bing
coredata.dc:description: Searching novel polyethylene oxide (PEO) based composite electrolyte that can be compatible with high voltage cathodes (> 4 V) at room temperature is a long-standing challenge, but essential to achieve high-energy-density for solid-state lithium (Li) metal batteries. Herein, we develop an advanced dual-salts reinforced PEO/garnet solid-state composite electrolyte (SCE) with high ionic conductivity of 9 × 10−4 S cm−1 and an electrochemical stability window up to ~ 4.7 V, where the lithium bis(oxalate)borate (LiBOB) is used as additive with LiClO4. The dual-salts reinforced SCE can achieve excellent room temperature cycling performance of LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811)/Li metal batteries. The multiplied polymer-ion interactions and formation of Li‒B‒O/C‒O species originated from the (oxalato)borate group of LiBOB effectively promotes the electrochemical stability of the PEO based composite electrolyte and its wetting properties with electrodes. Unwanted non-conductive decomposition products, such as Li2O and Li2CO3, and NCM particles cracking during cycling are successfully suppressed. The NCM811 solid-state cells using the optimized dual-salts composite electrolyte delivers high specific capacity of 190 mA h g−1 and exhibit stable cycling performance for more than 200 cycles at 25 °C.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic illustration of the (a) dual-salt solid-state NCM811 cell configuration and (b) mechanisms of achieving excellent high voltage cycling performance.
(a) Raman spectra of the ClO and LiBOB-added SCEs. (b) XRD patterns of LLZTO particles, ClO and ClO-BOB01 SCEs. (c) Ionic conductivities of the ClO and LiBOB-added SCEs.
Cyclic voltammetry (CV) of initial three cycles of (a) Li/ClO/Cu and (b) Li/ClO-BOB01/Cu cells at 0.1 mV s−1 and (c) electrochemical stability windows of ClO and LiBOB-added SCEs.

(a) Lithium plating-stripping test results and (b) the enlarged voltage profiles of Li–Li symmetrical cells using ClO and ClO-BOB01 SCEs. (c) Rate performance and (d) their corresponding charge-discharge curves of NCM811 batteries using ClO, ClO-BOB01 and ClO-BOB04 SCEs. (e) Long-term cycling performance of Li/NCM811 coin cells using ClO, ClO-BOB01 and ClO-BOB04 SCEs with operating voltage ranges from 2.8 to 4.3 V at 25 °C.

(a) EIS results of NCM811 cell assembled with ClO and ClO-BOB01 SCEs after 1st, 3rd, 10th, 20th and 40th cycles at charge state. (b) XRD patterns and SEM images of cathodes (large and small particles) after 40th cycles in the NCM811 cell assembled with (c, e) ClO, and (d, f) ClO-BOB01 SCEs. (g) C1s and B1s, Cl2p spectra of NCM811 cathodes after 40th charge. (h) C1s, O1s and B1s, Cl2p spectra of lithium anode surfaces after 40th charge.

head.ce:title: (Oxalato)borate: The key ingredient for polyethylene oxide based composite electrolyte to achieve ultra-stable performance of high voltage solid-state LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2/lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Searching novel polyethylene oxide (PEO) based composite electrolyte that can be compatible with high voltage cathodes (> 4 V) at room temperature is a long-standing challenge, but essential to achieve high-energy-density for solid-state lithium (Li) metal batteries. Herein, we develop an advanced dual-salts reinforced PEO/garnet solid-state composite electrolyte (SCE) with high ionic conductivity of 9 × 10−4 S cm−1 and an electrochemical stability window up to ~ 4.7 V, where the lithium bis(oxalate)borate (LiBOB) is used as additive with LiClO4. The dual-salts reinforced SCE can achieve excellent room temperature cycling performance of LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811)/Li metal batteries. The multiplied polymer-ion interactions and formation of Li‒B‒O/C‒O species originated from the (oxalato)borate group of LiBOB effectively promotes the electrochemical stability of the PEO based composite electrolyte and its wetting properties with electrodes. Unwanted non-conductive decomposition products, such as Li2O and Li2CO3, and NCM particles cracking during cycling are successfully suppressed. The NCM811 solid-state cells using the optimized dual-salts composite electrolyte delivers high specific capacity of 190 mA h g−1 and exhibit stable cycling performance for more than 200 cycles at 25 °C.

Stable charge–discharge performance of 4 V NCM solid-state battery are realized via addition of LiBOB salts to conventional single salt plasticized PEO solid-state composite electrolyte. Polymer electrolyte decomposition and active materials cracking at high voltage are suppressed by multiplied polymer-ion interactions and formation of stable C‒O/Li‒B‒O containing solid electrolyte interphase, leading to strikingly improvement in capacity retention.
ga1

ce:section.ce:para: The invention of Li ion batteries (LIBs) has led to the revolution in design and functionability of portable electronics as well as electric vehicles. However, further breakthroughs are urgently required for current LIBs in order to fulfill the proliferating demands in energy density, cycling performance, safety and cost effectiveness of future applications. Solid-state batteries which employ solid-state electrolytes instead of conventional flammable liquid electrolytes are regarded as the ultimate solution for achieving high safety and energy density of Li metal batteries [1]. Polymer electrolyte such as polyethylene oxide (PEO) has aroused intensive investigation owing to its superior processability, excellent flexibility and chemical compatibility with lithium metal [2]. However, the PEO solid-state electrolytes are still applied in LiFePO4 cathode batteries with a relatively low potential of less than 4 V at a high temperature of 60 °C, which restricts the practical application of PEO-based solid-state batteries [1–4].

Limited attempts related to the mechanism of PEO decomposition above 4 V and its corresponding solving strategies have been explored heretofore. One effective approach is the use of oxygen-vacancy-rich fillers (e.g. Ca‒CeO2), which helps dissociate the Li salt, produce free Li ions, and enhance ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability [5]. Another approach is the construction of interfacial protection layer such as Li ion conducting Li1.4Al0.4Ti1.6(PO4)3 and Li1.5Al0.5Ge1.5(PO4)3 nanolayer on cathode surface [6,7]. These protection layers are able to isolate PEO electrolyte from chemical reactions with cathode materials at high operating potentials (exceeding 4.2 V). However, above solid-state electrolytes also need to be operated at high temperature. In addition, such coating procedures usually need extra processing technology which is complicated for industry production. The use of multilayer polymer electrolyte is another approach for improving high voltage performance of PEO-based solid-state electrolyte [8,9]. Stable high voltage cycling performance was realized in a PEO-based solid-state battery by introducing a thin Li[(CF3)3COBF3] salt PEO-based “contacting layer” between normal PEO/SN/LiTFSI electrolyte and electrodes (i.e. Li anode, LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode). Such improvement is related to the formation of stable electrolyte/electrode interphases (i.e. solid electrolyte interface (SEI) and cathode electrolyte interface (CEI)) which protect the electrolyte from decomposition on electrode surface [9]. Furthermore, chain structure of PEG can also be modified to enhance electrochemical stability of the electrolyte. Replacing the ‒OH group of PEG with ‒OCH3 group were reported to extend the electrochemical stability window of the electrolyte to > 4.3 V. The Li/LiNi0.5Mn0.3Co0.2O2 pouch cell using the modified electrolyte delivered a reversible initial specific capacity of 135 mA h g−1 (i.e. 0.47 mA h cm−2) and a capacity retention of ~ 90% after 100 cycles at 60 °C [10].

Unfortunately, PEO-based electrolytes are usually tested at temperature > 60 °C due to the low room temperature ionic conductivity caused by recrystallization of PEO [11–13]. The synchronous addition of plasticizer (e.g. ethylene carbonate (EC) [14], polyethylene glycol (PEG) [3], succinonitrile (SN) [15] etc.), Li ion conductive fillers (e.g. Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) [16], Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP) [17] and Li10GeP2S12 (LGPS) [18] etc.) or non-conductive anion trapping fillers (e.g. Ca–CeO2 [5], h-BN [19] etc.) can effectively enhance the area of amorphous phase, Li ion mobility and establish fast Li ion conducting channels in the PEO-based solid-state polymer electrolyte [20]. Such plasticized SCEs not only show great enhancement in Li ion conductivity at relatively lower temperature (< 60 °C), but also exhibit low interfacial resistance with electrodes, which are crucial to the cycling performance of solid-state batteries. Designing new strategies to obtain advanced SCEs with high voltage operation ability and excellent Li ion conductivity at room temperature simultaneously is quite essential since it enables the direct match of PEO-based electrolyte with high-voltage cathodes, which make the scalable fabrication of high-energy-density solid-state batteries become feasible and affordable.

The battery performance could be profoundly influenced when using dual lithium salts combination in the electrolyte, via modification of the constituent in the SEI and CEI [21]. For instance, lithium borate salts have been frequently supplemented with fluorine containing lithium salts (i.e. LiPF6, LiTFSI) in conventional liquid electrolyte to improve thermal stability, high voltage performance and eliminate dendrite formation by forming a flexible, stable and fast Li-ion conducting CEI and SEI [22,23]. Therein, LiF is usually reported in the CEI and SEI when using fluorine containing lithium salts, but its actual function is controversial. On one hand, LiF is reported to form a robust and conductive SEI with Li2BOx, which benefits cycle stability [24]. On the other hand, LiF is also claimed to be highly resistive and lead to sluggish Li+ transport kinetics and consequent capacity fading [25]. The approach of adding functional salts is highly expected to improve the performance of conventional PEO-based solid-state electrolytes. However, the effect of this strategy on ionic conductivity, high voltage stability of solid-state electrolytes and interfacial properties between electrodes remains unknown.

Herein, we report a dual-salt plasticized PEO/EC/LiClO4/Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) SCE for high voltage solid-state LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2(NCM811)/lithium metal battery ( Fig. 1a). The lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB) is added into the PEO/EC/LiClO4/LLZTO SCE to enhance the Li ion conductivity and SCE/electrode interfacial stability for excellent high voltage cycling performance of solid-state NCM811/lithium metal battery. The enhancement of Li ion conductivity is achieved by synergistic effects of EC, LLZTO and Li salts on PEO crystallinity and salt dissociation. Also, the electrochemical stability window of the solid-state PEO-based electrolyte is widened by multiplied polymer-ion interactions and formation of stable and Li ion conductive C‒O/Li‒B‒O containing SEI and CEI originated from (oxalato)borate group of LiBOB (Fig. 1b). The generation of nonconductive polymer decomposition products and cracks of NCM particle during cycling at high voltage are suppressed. As a result, the solid-state NCM battery using the LiBOB-added dual salt SCE delivered initial specific capacity of 190 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C and stable cycling for more than 200 cycles at 25 °C. Furthermore, lithium difluoro(oxalato)borate(LiDFOB), which is known to form borate and LiF-rich SEI [26], is also added, instead, to the PEO/EC/LiClO4/LLZTO SCE for comparison. The results suggested that the presence of (oxalato)borate group in the electrolyte is more decisive, since similar enhancement of battery performance is obtained when the LiDFOB-added SCE is employed. This study provides significant insight in manipulating suitable components in SCEs for realizing high voltage solid-state Li batteries at room temperature.

The dual-salt SCEs are fabricated by direct adding of LiBOB or LiDFOB salt to PEO/EC/LiClO4/LLZTO using conventional solution casting process. Hereafter, for simplicity, sample with EO:EC:LiClO4:LiBOB molar ratio of 8:4:1:0.x and PEO/LLZTO weight ratio of 1:0.2 were denoted by ClO-BOB0x. The PEO/EC/LiClO4/LLZTO denoted by ClO sample was also prepared. The intermolecular interactions before and after adding LiBOB into the SCE were determined using Raman spectrometry [27–33]. As shown in Fig. 2a, the C‒O/C‒C rotations (1070, 1135 cm−1), C‒H2 twist (1232, 1284 cm−1), C‒H2 scissor (1450, 1478 cm−1) and C‒H stretch (2933, 2893 cm−1) are found in form of well-separated doublets in the ClO sample, which is the vibrational fingerprint of amorphous PEO [28]. The fast Li ion conducting amorphous phase of PEO is obtained even at room temperature due to the combined plasticization effects of Li salts, EC and LLZTO. The LiClO4 salt are well dissociated as “free” ClO4
− anions and Li ions in the amorphous structure without ion-pairing as indicated by the distinct Raman peaks at 457, 624 and 931 cm−1 [34]. The Li ions, provided by the Li salts and LLZTO, coordinate with oxygen within the crown-ether conformation of PEO as indicated by the appearance of Raman peak at 865 cm−1 (labeled as #), which accounts for the suppressed crystallinity [28,35]. Furthermore, the EC molecules are also found mainly contributing to the amorphous phase of PEO without strong EC-Li ions interactions in the ClO sample, as no splitting or shifting of Raman peaks at 715 and 893 cm−1 are observed [31,34]. After incorporation of LiBOB into the composite electrolytes, three distinct Raman peaks at 346, 374, 1828 cm−1 and a shoulder peak at 728 cm−1 emerge and become stronger with increasing content of LiBOB (i.e. ClO-BOB04, ClO-BOB06). These emerging peaks belong to the bending of O˭C‒C˭O in “free” BOB− ions (346 and 374 cm−1) and the existence of Li+∙∙∙BOB− ion pairs (1828 cm−1) [29]. Also, both PEO- and EC-Li+ ions interactions became stronger with higher Li salt content, as suggested by increasing intensity of 865 cm−1 peak, 728 cm−1 shoulder peak and the shift towards higher frequency of the EC ring breathing peak [29,31,32]. The results suggest that the Li+ ions are preferentially solvated by PEO molecules at lower LiBOB salt content, nevertheless, the interactions between Li+, EC and BOB− ions become more substantial when further increasing the concentration of salt, which may affect ionic conducting properties of the SCE. Similarly, the polymer matrix can also maintain highly amorphous when LiDFOB is added instead (Fig. S1), the addition of higher content of LiDFOB results in the appearance of two peaks at 338 and 368 cm−1, which are related to bending of F‒B‒F and O˭C‒C in uncoordinated DFOB− ions [36,37].

The amorphous structure of the SCE is also supported by the typical broad bump at 2θ = 23° in XRD pattern and the missing endothermic peak at ~ 57 °C in DSC as shown in Figs. 2b and S1, respectively. Furthermore, the fast conducting cubic garnet phase (space group: Ia-3d) of the LLZTO particles is confirmed in all samples as shown by the sharp peaks in the XRD spectrum [38]. Similar to conventional solid-state polymer electrolyte, the ionic conductivities of the SCEs increase with increasing temperature as shown in Fig. 2c. The room temperature ionic conductivity of ClO is enhanced after adding LiBOB from 5 × 10−4 S cm−1 to 9 × 10−4 S cm−1 in ClO-BOB01, and then followed by a rapid deterioration to 1 × 10−4 S cm−1 in ClO-BOB06. The higher ionic conductivity results from the synergistic effects of LLZTO particles, EC and dual lithium salts. The LLZTO particles provides alternative Li ion conductive pathways in the SCE such as the polymer-LLZTO interface and inside the particles [20,39]. The EC acting as a plasticizer prevents PEO recrystallization and promotes dissociation of Li salts (LiClO4 and LiBOB). In addition, the crystallinity of PEO is decreased by the synergistic effect of both salts. As a result, more free Li ions are released to along the PEO chain, thus enhancing Li ion conductivity [5]. However, further increasing salt content leads to structural changes which hinder ion transfer. Li+∙∙∙BOB− ion pairing and aggregation may result in lowering of mobility and amount of Li+ charge carriers [32]. On the other hand, adding excess salts may increase polymer viscosity and obstruct polymer chain motion, leading to lower ionic conductivity and the increased Tg (Fig. S2). Therefore, the EO/LiClO4 ratio of 8:1 is chosen due to the highest room temperature Li ion conductivity of the single-salt PEO/LiClO4 electrolyte [40], meaning the effect of LiClO4 on suppressing PEO recrystallization is maximized with such EO/LiClO4 ratio. In the case of the dual-salt system, the synergistic effect of both salts further suppresses PEO recrystallization by increasing the amount of dispersive Li ions and preventing the formation of less mobile ion pairs.

The cyclic voltammetry (CV) of the initial three cycles of Li/ClO/Cu exhibit an irreversible reduction peak at ~ 1.4 V (indicated as A) and a pair of reversible oxidation and reduction peaks (indicated as B and C) apart from the typical Li plating and stripping peaks between −0.5 V and 0.5 V( Fig. 3a). These peaks are often observed in PEO-based electrolytes and are related to the SEI formation (peak A) and redox reaction of electrode surface species, such as oxides (peak B and C) [41,42]. In contrast, only one irreversible reduction peak (indicated as D) is observed at ~ 1.2 V in the CV curve of Li/ClO-BOB01/Cu cell (Fig. 3b), suggesting the different nature of SEI after the addition of LiBOB. Furthermore, the higher current density (an order of magnitude higher) and more repeatable lithium stripping-plating peaks indicate that the SEI formed by ClO-BOB01 SCE is more stable and less resistive than that by ClO SCE [43]. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves present that the addition of LiBOB salt is beneficial for enhancing the electrochemical window of the electrolyte as shown in Fig. 3c. The electrochemical stability is enhanced from 4 V in ClO to ~ 4.7 V in the ClO-BOB SCEs. The improvement in electrochemical stability is attributed to the synergistic effect of Li salts in the SCE. The highly dissociated salts promote polymer-ion interactions as revealed by Raman studies and form stable Li ion conductive electrode/electrolyte interphases which suppress both oxidation and reduction of the SCE.

The effect of galvanostatic cycling on interfacial stability and overpotential between the SCEs and lithium anode is studied via Li plating and stripping test at various currents in a Li/SCE/Li symmetrical cell as shown in Fig. 4a. All samples show low overpotential of < 0.1 V and excellent reversibility at current density of 0.05 and 0.1 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4b). After further long-term cycling at 0.2 mA cm−2, a continuous enlargement of overpotential is observed in the ClO sample due to the formation of insulating surface film on the lithium [44]. Adding LiBOB to the ClO sample can effectively suppress degradation and improve interfacial stability upon long-term cycling. Also, no short-circuit is observed in all samples even after 700 h cycling, meaning uniform lithium deposition with no dendrite formation.

The NCM811/ClO/Li cell exhibits extremely poor rate performance at 25 °C, as shown in Fig. 4c and d, with substantial drop in capacity even at 0.1 C and delivers negligible capacity when increasing rate to > 0.2 C. Interestingly, striking improvement in cycle performance is achieved in the NCM811 cell using the newly developed dual-salt SCEs, as shown in Figs. 4c, d, S3 and S4. The variation of discharge specific capacities of NCM batteries using ClO-BOB SCEs follow a very similar trend with ionic conductivities of the SCEs as described previously. For instance, the NCM battery using the ClO-BOB01 SCE delivers the highest reversible specific capacities of 190 mA h g−1 when cycle at 0.1 C, much higher than that using ClO SCE (i.e. 167 mA h g−1), and exhibits excellent charge-discharge performance at all designated rates at room temperature. The high specific capacity and stable cycling performance of the cell using ClO-BOB01 SCE are attributed to the improved Li ion conductivity, enhanced electrolyte electrochemical stability and intimate electrolyte-electrode contact resulting from the synergistic effects of EC, LLZTO, LiClO4 and LiBOB salts in the PEO-based electrolyte [5]. The areal capacity of NCM811/ClO-BOB01/Li cells can even be further enhanced via increasing the weight of active material loading as shown in Fig. S5. A high areal capacity of ~ 1.1 mA h cm−2 can be achieved at a high cathode loading of 7 mg cm−2, confirming the great potential for practical application of the solid-state NCM battery.

The capacity retention of solid-state NCM811 batteries using ClO-BOB SCEs are studied by cycling the coin cell for 200 cycles as shown in Fig. 4e. The cells are firstly cycled at 0.1 C for 3 cycles for SEI and CEI formation and better interfacial contact between electrolyte and electrodes before further cycling at 0.2 C. All NCM811/Li batteries using the ClO SCE experience sharp specific capacity drop at ~ 30–40 cycles and then turn dead analogously. The use of the ClO-BOB SCEs is shown to have distinct improvement on cycle reversibility of the solid-state NCM811 cell. Apart from specific capacity, the capacity retention and variations in charge-discharge curve after long-term cycling of the solid-state NCM battery are also highly affected by the amount of LiBOB added to the SCE (Fig. S3). Although the specific capacity drops when using SCEs with higher LiBOB content, adding more LiBOB to the SCEs (e.g. ClO-BOB04) benefit long-term charge-discharge stability of the NCM battery. The capacity retention of 70% and 87% can be obtained after 200 cycles in the solid-state NCM811 batteries using ClO-BOB01 and ClO-BOB04 SCEs, respectively. The excellent long-term charge-discharge stability can also be achieved when using another type of cathode material such as LiFePO4 (LFP). As shown in Fig. S6, the LFP/ClO-BOB01/Li cell delivers a specific capacity of ~ 152 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and 25 °C and excellent capacity retention of ~ 95% after 200 cycles, outperformed that of using ClO SCE and other PEO-based solid-state composite electrolytes [3,4,45].

Interestingly, such an improvement in cycle stability can also be achieved when replacing LiBOB with another (oxalato)borate group-containing lithium salt (i.e. LiDFOB) as shown in Figs. S3, S4 and S7. Apart from LiCl and common organic species, both LiF and Li‒B‒O are detected by XPS in SEI and CEI when the LiDFOB-containing SCE is being used (Fig. S8). The presence of both Li‒B‒O and LiF, however, did not cause significant changes in lithium plating-stripping (Fig. S7) and battery cycling performance (Fig. S4) when compared with that of ClO-BOB SCEs. This indicates that the presence of (oxalato)borate group in the SCE is crucial for suppressing side reactions which deteriorate the capacity during the long-term charge-discharge process.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) are performed to monitor the changes after 40 cycles which affect the charge-discharge performance of the NCM/ClO/Li and NCM/ClO-BOB01/Li cells. As shown in Fig. 5a, the EIS plot can be divided into 3 parts, the x-intercept which is related to bulk resistance (Rb) of the electrolyte and two overlapped semi-circles which are related to resistance of solid-state electrolyte interphase (RSEI) and charge transfer (RCT) respectively [46,47]. The equivalent model of the EIS is provided in the inset of Fig. 5a. It is shown that the Rb of all samples do not have significant changes upon cycling, meaning the ionic conductivities of the electrolytes are unaffected by the charge-discharge process. Yet, a gradual increase in RSEI and RCT is resulted upon increasing number of cycles, indicating a continuous growth of less conductive interphases on the electrodes. The RSEI and RCT of the battery with ClO SCE is found to increase more tremendously than that with LiBOB added ones, and become even worse when the rate is increased to 0.2 C. This suggests that the rapid failure of the NCM/ClO/Li battery is related to the malfunction of the interphase layer between electrolyte and electrodes. The XRD peaks of the NCM/ClO/Li cathode after 40th charge, as shown in Fig. 5b, are identified to be the hexagonal α-NaFeO2-type structure with space group R-3 m of the NCM811 active materials [48,49], while the broad bump at 25° is related to the Super-P carbon or remaining amorphous PEO. Minor peaks correspond to LLZTO particles are also observed in the cathodes. There is no significant difference in microstructure when comparing with cathodes of NCM/ClO/Li battery and pristine NCM811 particles, i.e. in discharged state. In contrast, peaks shift as indicated by arrows are observed in cathodes of NCM/ClO-BOB01/Li cells. Such shifts are reported to be the result of normal lattice contraction caused by delithiation from the layered structure during charging process [50]. Therefore, it can be deduced that the active materials in the NCM/ClO/Li battery failed after discharging and cannot be charged up after 40 cycles. Severe intergranular cracking is observed by SEM, as shown in Fig. 5c and e, on the active materials of NCM/ClO/Li cell, especially in larger particles (> 10 µm). While, the morphology of active materials in NCM/ClO-BOB01/Li (Fig. 5d and f) cells remain visibly unchanged. The intergranular cracking of NCM particles is related to the anisotropic volumetric shrinkage of the primary active particles during delithiation which raised by the presence of highly Li-deficient phase and poor ionic contact [51,52]. No cracking is found in smaller secondary active particles in all samples, possibly because of the shorter ionic pathway such that lithium ions are more uniformly distributed between the primary particles. The CV curves of the Li/NCM solid-state batteries using ClO-BOB01 electrolyte present sharper oxidation and reduction peaks, higher current density, lower overpotential and highly repeatable peak position than that of NCM/Li battery using ClO electrolyte (Fig. S9). This indicates that the addition of LiBOB leads to highly reversible and faster Li ion diffusion in electrolyte and interfacial layers, thus preventing active particles from cracking and improving charge-discharge stability [5,53]. In addition, a stable CEI containing Li‒B‒O, Ni‒B and C‒O species is formed on the NCM particles when using LiBOB salt in the electrolyte, which also can effectively protect the NCM particles from cracking and improve cycling stability at room temperature.

The surface constituent of NCM cathode and the Li anode after 40th charge is studied by XPS as shown in Fig. 5g and h, respectively. The C1s spectrum of cathodes in all cells contain a major peak at 284.7 eV, which is assigned to the C‒C specie in conductive carbons and PVDF binder, and two minor peaks at 286.5 and 289.3 eV, which are related to common contaminants such as hydrocarbons (C‒H) and lithium carbonate (Li2CO3) respectively [54]. In addition, the surface of NCM cathodes consist of Li salt-related components coming from the SCE. For instance, inorganic LiCl is found in all samples and presented by the two peaks at 196.2 and 198.7 eV (i.e. Cl2p1/2 and Cl2p3/2) in the Cl2p spectrum [55]. Using LiBOB salt in the electrolyte result in the formation of Li‒B‒O, Ni‒B and C‒O species containing CEI, as shown in the B1s and C1s spectrum, which is attributed to decomposition products of the (oxalato)borate group in BOB ions [56]. In case of SEI, peaks assigned to C‒C, C‒H, C‒O, C˭O, Li2CO3 and Li2O, which are commonly found in SEI when using conventional liquid electrolytes [56], are observed in the C1s and O1s spectra for sample using the ClO SCE. The formation of non-conductive and insoluble inorganic compounds in SEI when using liquid electrolyte affects the long-term cycling performance of the battery [50], whereas, the liquid electrolyte still can penetrate through the pores of the SEI, providing a fast Li ion conducting liquid-phase, which maintain good connection between electrolyte and electrode in short term [57]. In contrast, the formation of non-conductive compounds in SEI blocks Li ion diffusion and results in substantial drop in capacity when using ClO SCE. Similar to that in CEI, salt decomposition products such as Li‒Cl, Li‒B‒O and C‒O are also obtained in SEI in an analogous manner for all characterized cells. As revealed by the C1s and O1s spectra, the addition of LiBOB salt to the electrolyte showed a clear effect in suppressing the formation of Li2CO3 and Li2O, which are known decomposition products of EC and PEO, during cycling [58,59].

Summarizing the discoveries above, the vigorous drop in specific capacity of NCM battery using ClO SCE upon cycling is attributed to deteriorations of both cathode materials and SEI. Firstly, severe intergranular cracking occurs on the secondary particles of NCM, which results in contact lost between particles and the SCE. Secondly, the polymer matrix of the SCE decomposed upon cycling to form non-conductive Li2O and Li2CO3 on Li surface, which block Li ion diffusion between electrolyte and the lithium anode. The addition of LiBOB salt to the electrolyte improves Li ion conductivity and triggers the formation of Li‒B‒O/C‒O containing interphases which can effectively improve “wetting” properties between PEO based composite electrolyte and the NCM active particles and eliminate nonuniform volume changes of the NCM primary particles. Meanwhile, formation of unwanted electrolyte decomposition products such as Li2O and Li2CO3 on lithium anode surface are suppressed via improving electrochemical stability of the SCEs by ion-polymer interactions in the electrolyte and the formation of stable SEI, which allows the rapid Li ion transfer.

In summary, a dual-salts plasticized PEO/EC/LiClO4/Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 SCE is developed for high voltage solid-state NCM811/lithium metal battery. The combination of LiBOB with LiClO4 salts can greatly enhance the Li ion conductivity and electrochemical stability of the SCE via increasing the amount of mobile Li ions, increasing polymer-ion interactions and the formation of stable SEI and CEI. High room temperature ionic conductivity of 9 × 10−4 S cm−1 and high electrochemical stability window of ~ 4.7 V are obtained in ClO-BOB01 SCE. In addition, the Li‒B‒O/C‒O containing interphases formed from the (oxalato)borate group in LiBOB can effectively protect the NCM811 particles from cracking and suppress the formation of non-conductive decomposition products on electrodes’ surface during cycling, which ensures the more uniform ionic transport pathway between the SCE and both electrodes. As a result, the NCM811 battery using the dual-salts plasticized SCE can deliver specific capacity of 190 mA h g−1 and also present excellent cycling stability for more than 200 cycles. The synergistic effects caused by adding (oxalato)borate-containing lithium salts in the solid-state composite electrolyte is a promising strategy for the realization of advanced high voltage solid-state high nickel ternary positive electrode/lithium metal batteries.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Dr. Samson Ho-Sum Cheng received his B.E., M.S. and Ph.D. from City University of Hong Kong under the supervision of Dr. Chi-Yuen Chung in 2011, 2014 and 2018, respectively. He was a visiting scholar in the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology from 2017 to 2018. He is currently a postdoctoral fellow in the College of Materials Science and Engineering at Shenzhen University. His recent research interests are solid-state electrolytes, solid-state Li-ion and Li-sulfur batteries.

Dr. Chen Liu is an assistant Professor in the College of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenzhen University. She received her Ph.D. degree from department of physics and Materials Science, City University of Hong Kong in 2017. Her research interest is in the area of polymer composites/ nanomaterials for electrochemical and energy applications, especially the design of solid composite electrolytes for lithium/sodium solid-state batteries.

Fangyan Zhu received her B.S. degree from Jiangsu University in 2018. She is currently a master degree candidate in the College of Materials Science and Engineering at Shenzhen University. Her research interest focuses on the development of novel solid composite electrolytes for solid-state lithium batteries.

Liang Zhao received his bachelor degree from Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Shandong University in 2017. Now he is a Ph.D. candidate in Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University under the supervision of Prof. Feiyu Kang and Prof. Yan-Bing He. His research interest mainly focuses on lithium-ion batteries.

Rong Fan was born in Sichuan, China. She received her M.S. from Shenzhen University in 2020. She is now a research assistant in the School of Chemical Biology & Biotechnology at Peking University Shenzhen Graduate school. Her research interests are all-solid-state lithium batteries and large area perovskite solar cells.

Ir. Dr. Chi-Yuen Chung received his Ph.D. from University of Hong Kong. He is currently an associate professor in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at City University of Hong Kong and a member of the Hong Kong Institution of Engineers (HKIE). His research interests are shape memory alloys and battery-related materials.

Prof. Jiaoning Tang received his Ph.D. from Xi'an Jiaotong University. He worked as a post-doctoral fellow at State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces in Xiamen University from 1994 to 1996. He is currently a professor in College of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenzhen university. His research interest is in the area of functional nanomaterials, composites and membranes.

Prof. Xierong Zeng received his Ph.D. from Northwestern Polytechnical University and now is a professor in Shenzhen university. He is the director of Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Special Functional Materials, Shenzhen Engineering Laboratory of Advanced Technology Ceramics. His research interest mainly focuses on the study of microstructure and properties of amorphous metal and carbon materials.

Prof. Yan-Bing He is currently an associate professor of Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University. He received his Ph.D. degree from the Department of Applied Chemistry, Tianjin University in 2010. He worked as a post-doctoral fellow at Graduate School at Shenzhen, Tsinghua University from 2010 to 2012 and a visiting scholar at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology from 2012 to 2013. His research interests mainly focus on lithium ion power batteries and materials, solid-state electrolyte and lithium metal anode.
